Title:
Diversity of Carbendazim-Sensitive and -Resistant Populations
of Colletotrichum spp. from Infected Strawberry and Yam in Hubei
Province, China
Abstract:
The ascomycete fungus Colletotrichum gloeosporioides is a
devastating plant pathogen with a wide host range and worldwide
distribution. Carbendazim has been widely used to control anthracnose
caused by the C. gloeosporioides complex in China for more than 30
years, and resistant phenotype to carbendazim have been reported in
southern and eastern China. In this study, 128 Colletotrichum isolates
were collected from different geographical regions in Hubei Province,
China, from 2012 to 2015. Approximately 51.6% of randomly selected C.
gloeosporioides species complex isolates from various cultivars in
strawberry and yam orchards in Hubei Province showed resistance to
carbendazim. The majority (73.8%) of isolates from diseased strawberry
and 28.6% of isolates from diseased yam in Hubei Province were resistant
to carbendazim. The isolates tested in this study belong to five
species, and the frequencies of resistant isolates differed across
Colletotrichum species. Resistant isolates were found in C. siamense and
C. fructicola. All 48 isolates of C. siamense were resistant to
carbendazim, and 32.1% of C. fructicola isolates were resistant. In
contrast, all isolates of C. gloeosporioides, C. nymphaeae and C.
aenigma were sensitive to carbendazim. Î²-tubulin 2 (TUB2) gene structure
analysis showed that no differences in TUB2 gene structure among the
five species led to species-specific resistance to carbendazim. Sequence
analysis of the TUB2 genes of ten sensitive, three moderately resistant
(MR) and six highly resistant (HR) representative isolates of C.
gloeosporioides complex and C. nymphaeae from strawberry and yam showed
that highly carbendazim-resistant isolates harbored the E198A mutation
in the TUB2 gene, whereas moderately carbendazim-resistant isolates
harbored the F200Y mutation in the TUB2 gene. Phylogenetic tree analysis
showed that sensitive, MR and HR isolates were grouped within separate
clusters regardless of species, if the mutated codon positions of TUB2
were included in the phylogenetic tree analysis. In contrast, sensitive,
MR and HR isolates could be grouped within separate clusters if the
mutated codon positions of TUB2 was not included in the phylogenetic
analysis. The results indicated that field methyl benzimidazole
carbamate (MBC) fungicide resistance to carbendazim is not derived from
the same ancestor.
